content_parts.text: —The identity of the author is not known.
—Although the story occurs during the reign of Nebuchadnezzar and the Assyrian domination of the Near East, the ideas and language place it somewhere in the second century BC.
The work was probably composed sometime during the reign of John Hyrcanus I (135–105 BC), high priest and king of Israel.
God protects His people from their enemies
God protects His people from their enemies
The Lord God works in mysterious ways throughout history through the agency of human beings, both evil and good, powerful and weak.

Judith's lesson to us is that our worship of God, trust in Him, and obedience to His commandments result in divine protection and salvation from our enemies, no matter how powerful those enemies seem to be in this world.
—The heroine of this story is Judith, meaning Jewess, the beautiful widow of a wealthy farmer, pious and of good reputation among her countrymen.
She single-handedly takes on Holofernes, the enemy of Israel, a general in Nebuchadnezzar's army.
